verses.text: This is the law of the guilt offering; it is most holy.
verses.comment: The guilt offering is called 'most holy,' showing a special level of sanctity. This foreshadows the ultimate sacrifice of Christ who is 'most holy.'

verses.text: In the place where they slaughter the burnt offering, they shall slaughter the guilt offering, and its blood shall be dashed against all sides of the altar.
verses.comment: The blood on the altar prefigures the shedding of Christ’s blood as a means of atonement for sin (Heb. 9:12-14).

verses.text: All its fat shall be offered, the fat tail, the fat that covers the entrails,
verses.comment: The fat, considered the best and set apart for God, points to the offering of our best to the Lord.

verses.text: The two kidneys with the fat that is on them at the loins, and the appendage of the liver, he shall remove with the kidneys.
verses.comment: This detailed ritual stresses obedience in worship, setting a precedent for reverence for worship traditions in the Church.

verses.text: The priest shall burn them on the altar as an offering made by fire to the LORD; it is a guilt offering.
verses.comment: The priest as mediator here points to the greater Priest who would intercede between God and man (Heb. 7:27).

verses.text: Every male among the priests may eat of it; it shall be eaten in a holy place; it is most holy.
verses.comment: By restricting consumption to priests and the holy place, the text conveys real presence and a holy communion—a type fulfilled by Christ’s gift of Himself in the Eucharist (1 Cor. 10:16).

verses.text: The guilt offering is like the sin offering; there is one law for them. The priest who makes atonement with it shall have it.
verses.comment: Atonement involves a mediating priest, again foreshadowing Christ’s unique priesthood and a sacramental understanding of forgiveness (John 20:23).

verses.text: The priest who offers anyone’s burnt offering shall have for himself the skin of the burnt offering that he has offered.
verses.comment: Priests benefit from the sacrifice, showing a connection between sacred ministry and provision—a basis for reverence toward holy orders.

verses.text: Every grain offering baked in the oven, and all that is prepared in a pan or griddle, shall belong to the priest who offers it.
verses.comment: The detailed prescriptions for offerings reinforce the dignity and structure of liturgical worship.

verses.text: And every grain offering, mixed with oil or dry, shall belong to all the sons of Aaron, one as much as another.
verses.comment: Equal distribution among priests promotes unity and points to the Church’s communal nature (Acts 2:42-47).

verses.text: This is the law of the sacrifice of peace offerings that one may offer to the LORD.
verses.comment: Peace offerings foreshadow the true peace between God and man, brought through Christ (Romans 5:1).

verses.text: If he brings it as a thanksgiving, then he shall offer with the thanksgiving sacrifice unleavened cakes mixed with oil, unleavened wafers smeared with oil, and cakes of fine flour well mixed with oil.
verses.comment: The unleavened cakes and oil anticipate elements later used in Christian ritual and thanksgiving (Eucharist means 'thanksgiving').

verses.text: With cakes of leavened bread he shall offer his sacrifice of thanksgiving with the sacrifice of peace offerings.
verses.comment: Leavened and unleavened bread together suggest unity in diversity within the worshiping community.

verses.text: And from it he shall offer one out of each offering as a gift to the LORD; it shall belong to the priest who dashes the blood of the peace offerings.
verses.comment: Part of every offering is set apart for God and His ministers, an image of the special place of ministerial priesthood.

verses.text: The flesh of the sacrifice of his thanksgiving peace offering shall be eaten on the day of his offering. He shall not leave any of it until morning.
verses.comment: Consuming the offering immediately shows reverence for the sacred, hinting at the discipline of communion and not treating holy things lightly (1 Cor. 11:27-29).

verses.text: But if the sacrifice of his offering is a vow or a freewill offering, it shall be eaten on the day he offers his sacrifice, and on the next day what remains of it shall be eaten.
verses.comment: Some offerings may be consumed over more than one day, showing gradations in ritual practices and flexibility in worship.

verses.text: But what remains of the flesh of the sacrifice on the third day shall be burned with fire.
verses.comment: Defining limits for consuming offerings respects the holiness of the ritual and prevents corruption of what is sacred.

verses.text: If any of the flesh of the sacrifice of his peace offering is eaten on the third day, he who offers it shall not be accepted, neither shall it be credited to him; it is tainted, and the person who eats of it shall bear his iniquity.
verses.comment: Improper reception of a sacred meal leads to exclusion; a warning about treating the sacred with respect (Heb. 10:28-29).

verses.text: Flesh that touches any unclean thing shall not be eaten; it shall be burned with fire. As for flesh, everyone who is clean may eat it.
verses.comment: Maintaining ritual purity before partaking of sacred food is a type for approaching the new covenant with proper disposition.

verses.text: But the person who eats the flesh of the sacrifice of the LORD’s peace offerings while an uncleanness is on him, that person shall be cut off from his people.
verses.comment: To be 'cut off' means excommunication from the community. One must be reconciled before approaching the sacred (see 1 Cor. 11:27).

verses.text: And if anyone touches an unclean thing, whether human uncleanness or an unclean animal or any unclean detestable thing, and then eats of the flesh of the LORD’s peace offerings, that person shall be cut off from his people.
verses.comment: The laws of purity highlight the seriousness of preparation for communion with God.

verses.text: The LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
verses.comment: A new section begins, marked by the divine speech formula.

verses.text: Speak to the people of Israel, saying, ‘You shall eat no fat of ox or sheep or goat.’
verses.comment: Fat is reserved for God alone as the 'best portion' in sacrifice, expressing the holiness of the sacrificial meal.

verses.text: The fat of an animal that dies of itself and the fat of what is torn by beasts may be used for any other purpose, but you must not eat it.
verses.comment: Even permissible uses do not include eating; keeping clear boundaries shows respect for sacrifice.

verses.text: For whoever eats the fat of animals, from which an offering by fire may be made to the LORD, shall be cut off from his people.
verses.comment: To wrongly appropriate the portion belonging to God results in exclusion—pointing again to the need for proper respect for what is devoted to God.

verses.text: Moreover, you shall eat no blood whatever, whether of bird or of animal, in any of your dwelling places.
verses.comment: The prohibition against blood, which contains life, forms the basis for the later Christian understanding of the blood of Christ as bringing true life (John 6:53-54).

verses.text: Whoever eats any blood, that person shall be cut off from his people.
verses.comment: The seriousness of the penalty underscores the life-giving power of blood, which is why the Church so highly esteems Christ’s blood in the sacraments.

verses.text: The LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
verses.comment: Another new section in the law, emphasizing God's continuing revelation.

verses.text: Speak to the people of Israel, saying, ‘Whoever brings the sacrifice of his peace offerings to the LORD shall bring his offering to the LORD from the sacrifice of his peace offerings.’
verses.comment: Each worshipper brings offerings personally, highlighting the necessity of personal participation in worship.

verses.text: His own hands shall bring the offerings made by fire to the LORD; he shall bring the fat with the breast, that the breast may be waved as a wave offering before the LORD.
verses.comment: Lay participation in sacrificial liturgy anticipates the shared role of priesthood and laity in Christian worship.

verses.text: The priest shall burn the fat on the altar, but the breast shall be for Aaron and his sons.
verses.comment: The sharing of the breast with the priestly family signifies the role of ordained ministry in communion with God’s people.

verses.text: And the right thigh you shall give to the priest as a contribution from your peace offerings.
verses.comment: Specific portions are reserved for the priest, prefiguring the support of God’s ministers (1 Cor. 9:13-14).

verses.text: Whoever among the sons of Aaron offers the blood of the peace offerings and the fat shall have the right thigh for his portion.
verses.comment: Those who serve at the altar share in what is offered, connecting sacred duty and sacramental grace.

verses.text: For the breast that is waved and the thigh that is contributed I have taken from the people of Israel, out of the sacrifices of their peace offerings, and have given them to Aaron the priest and to his sons, as a perpetual due from the people of Israel.
verses.comment: A perpetual due maintains both order and continuity, reflecting apostolic succession in the divine economy.

verses.text: This is the portion of Aaron and of his sons from the LORD’s offerings made by fire, as they were appointed to receive from the LORD on the day he presented them to serve as priests to the LORD.
verses.comment: The ministry is established by divine appointment; the call and institution of the ordained is sacramental and enduring.

verses.text: The LORD commanded this to be given them by the people of Israel, from the day that he anointed them. It is a perpetual statute throughout their generations.
verses.comment: Anointing and perpetuity point to the enduring nature of holy orders in God’s plan.

verses.text: This is the law for the burnt offering, the grain offering, the sin offering, the guilt offering, the ordination offering, and the peace offerings,
verses.comment: A summary statement, pointing to the fullness of sacrificial worship later fulfilled by Christ’s one sacrifice (Heb. 10:10).

verses.text: which the LORD commanded Moses on Mount Sinai, on the day he commanded the people of Israel to bring their offerings to the LORD, in the wilderness of Sinai.
verses.comment: All these instructions originate from God’s authority as revealed on Sinai, showing continuity with God’s covenant people.
